title: Like Brexit, the Hong Kong protests are creating rifts within families
text:
Many older people suggest that the protesters should stop disrupting the city and ‘get over it’. Meanwhile, the younger generation believe in fighting for their freedom ( Picture: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg via Getty Images)

Nearly seven months in, the Hong Kong protests show no signs of stopping.

Despite the movement’s longevity, however, there are plenty of people both in Hong Kong and across the world that disagree with it, and with the tactics that protesters have employed to achieve their goals.

It seems to be a generational divide, with many older people suggesting that the protesters should stop disrupting the city and ‘get over it’. Meanwhile, the younger generation believe in fighting for their freedom.

As the protests grow, so do the staunch divides within families like mine.

When the protests began, they were about vehement disapproval of a law that would allow for the extradition of people from Hong Kong to China to face trial for their crimes. Many argued that this would have consequences for Hong Kong’s freedom. Now, the movement has evolved – it’s about the running of the Hong Kong government, police brutality, and China’s ‘control’ over the city as a whole.

The protests have mostly had major support from the people of Hong Kong, with one pro-democracy and anti-Extradition Amendment Bill Movement (anti-ELAB) rally gaining a turnout of 1.7 million people in August – nearly 25 per cent of the entire population. People all over the world have also used the hashtag #Stand WithHK to show their support, as well as participating in solidarity rallies and protests in cities like Vancouver, Toronto, Sydney and London.

But, much like Brexit in the UK, this is an issue that has divided families. Even though the movement seems to have a lot of support, disagreements have sprung up, usually between parents and children surrounding the latter’s participation in the protests.

Many of the parents who oppose the movement are largely ignoring the multiple cases of police brutality and violence that have occurred in the last few months (Picture: Ed Jones/AFP via Getty Images)

My family has been no different. Growing up in Hong Kong in the early 00s, with the legacy of Britain still woven into the fabric of the city, I was in favour of Hong Kong’s independence and the specific cultural elements that made us unique compared to mainland China. Even now, living in Britain and returning to visit Hong Kong once or twice a year, I am firm in my belief that there is a stark difference between Hong Kong and China.

But my family, who are all in their 60s or older, are more fond of China’s influence, despite witnessing first hand the effect it can have on our city. They believe it comes with many benefits, such as financial input into the city, as well as protection from any world powers who may seek to exploit Hong Kong as Britain once did.

One anonymous Hong Kong-er in her 20s told me that some of her family members ‘are against the protests because they think we are just disrupting Hong Kong, and that the extradition bill won’t affect us as long as we don’t break the law, which clearly is not the case’.

She says this has caused ‘quite a few arguments from time to time during dinner’, but she is ‘trying to change their minds [by] providing more facts about the bill… and about the police brutality’.

Another young Hong Kong-er told me that while his family ‘support the movement’, they ‘disagree with some of the methods [being used] to achieve what we want’.

He participates on the front line of the protests as a first aider, and said, ‘My mum doesn’t want me to be out there because it’s so dangerous with the police. I’ve been shot at and searched by the police. It’s caused multiple arguments between myself and my mum’.

A mum being concerned for her son’s safety is completely understandable, but it is crucial to remember that her fears stem from how he will be treated by the police, rather than the movement itself.

It is disheartening to see our own families counter-protesting and strongly opposing every effort to fight for what we believe is right

However, many of the parents who oppose the movement are largely ignoring the multiple cases of police brutality and violence that have occurred in the last few months. It is estimated that 1,800 rounds of tear gas had been fired by the Hong Kong police as of August 2019.

Advertisement

The police have also used rubber bullets, one of which hit a woman’s eye and blinded her. The rallies against police brutality have often been met with counter-protests in support of the police, and many of the attendees of these skew towards the older demographic.

My uncle was even in attendance at one counter-protest rally, bearing a sign that said (in Chinese): ‘I support the Hong Kong police. You can hit me if you want!’

This slogan has been a rallying cry against any reported incidents of police brutality, arguing that the police are ‘just doing their jobs’ and that it is in fact the protesters who have been causing the violence.

It is disheartening to see our own families counter-protesting and strongly opposing every effort to fight for what we believe is right. This largely youth-led movement needs support from across the generational divide if we are to succeed in our aims.

Currently, there doesn’t seem to be an easy answer as to how we can bridge that gap – but we need to stop it from widening. Supporters of the anti-ELAB movement need to have honest conversations with ourselves, and with the opposition we face within our own families, so we can have some hope of reaching a middle ground.

If we continue to fight, without attempting to understand the other side, Hong Kong is doomed.
